title-group.article-title: Antimicrobial, synergistic and antibiofilm activities of Myristica fragrans Houtt. Bioactive compounds and their derivatives

abstract.p: This study investigates the antimicrobial efficacy, synergistic interactions, antibiofilm activity, molecular docking studies, and drug-likeness properties of α-terpineol, 4-carvomenthenol, and their derivatives isolated from nutmeg and mace (Myristica fragrans Houtt.). α-Terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol were isolated from nutmeg essential oil and mace oleoresin respectively using column chromatography. Derivatization of α-Terpineol was derivatized into its ester, epoxide, ether, and allylic bromide while 4-carvomenthenol was derivatized to form its ester and epoxide. The antimicrobial activity of isolated compounds and their derivatives was assessed against Bacillus sp., Staphylococcus aureus, Yersinia enterocolitica and Escherichia coli followed by testing of their synergistic interactions with streptomycin. Additionally, the antibiofilm activity of the most effective treatments alone and in combination with was tested in combination with streptomycin was also evaluated. Molecular docking studies were conducted to assess binding affinities of the most effective treatments for DNA gyrase and transpeptidase followed byADMET profiling to evaluate their drug-likeness. The ester derivatives of α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol demonstrated the highest antibacterial potential with MIC values ranging from 40 to 170 µg/ml. Both the ester derivatives showed significant synergistic interactions with streptomycin and exhibited strong to intermediate antibiofilm activity against all the tested bacteria. Molecular docking studies indicated favorable binding affinities (–6.56 to − 4.31 kcal/mol) of ester derivatives for DNA gyrase and transpeptidase as compared to their parent compounds having favorable physicochemical properties, meeting drug-likeness criteria. α-Terpineol ester and 4-carvomenthenol ester exhibited promising antimicrobial potential, synergistic interaction with streptomycin and antibiofilm properties, suggesting their potential as novel therapeutic agents. Further development and investigation of these compounds are warranted to explore their applications in clinical settings.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-03152-y.

body.p: Contamination of food by microbes results in widespread illness, creating significant economic loss and public health challenges worldwide1. Foodborne illness constitutes a significant health concern in developing nations today, impacting nearly 600 million individuals annually, with approximately 4,20,000 deaths reported yearly2. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimated that combined foodborne and waterborne diarrheal diseases contributed to approximately 2.2 million deaths globally, affecting around 1 million individuals annually in the United Kingdom.

During the past three decades, new synthetic antibiotics have been manufactured by pharmaceutical industries to cure microbial infections. The use of such synthetic antibiotics always remains questionable due to their side effects3. The treatment of various microbial infections has become more challenging due to the increased resistance of bacterial pathogens against synthetic antibiotics4. Hence, it becomes necessary to search for new antimicrobial agents to combat these food-borne pathogens to extend the shelf life of food commodities, improve consumers’ health, reduce food wastage, and make the food business cost-effective.

Antimicrobial agents from natural sources like plants, animals and microorganisms serve as an alternative to these synthetic chemicals to ensure food safety without affecting the sensory qualities of food products5. They also contribute to enhance the nutritional value of food products and provide suitable alternatives to microbial resistance caused by antibiotics6. Hence, in this stressful daily routine with an unbalanced nutritional diet and even increasing rate of various chronic diseases, it becomes important to conduct studies on natural products of plant origin as antimicrobial agents to satisfy health-conscious consumers7.

Herbs and spices having numerous health benefits have gained a lot of attention to explore the antimicrobial potential of various bioactive compounds present in them8. Different bioactive compounds found in them work synergistically with one another and with the target enzymes or proteins of microbes. This interaction supports the immune system and serves as potential source of new chemical scaffolds for drug development9. Terpenoids constitute one such important class of bioactive compounds having huge biological potential involving antimicrobial properties10. The antimicrobial properties of diverse terpenoids stem from their inherent lipophilic nature, enabling them to effortlessly penetrate the cell membrane of microorganisms11. They have strong permeation-enhancing potential and have been generally recognized as safe (GRAS) adjuvants with relatively low and transient irritation12.

α-Terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol are monocyclic monoterpene alcohols found naturally in essential oils of several plants such as nutmeg tree, oregano, rosemary, marjoram and lemon peel13. Due to their pleasant lilac-like scent, they are commonly used in the production of cosmetics, soaps, perfumes, and antiseptic products, making them one of the most popular fragrance compounds. Additionally, their acetate derivatives and other simple esters are also utilized in perfumes and aromatic fragrances14. Moreover, α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol possess numerous biological and pharmacological properties such as antiulcer, antioxidant, anticancer, anticonvulsant, anti-inflammatory, insecticidal, antimicrobial and antinociceptive13,15–17. Both the compounds i.e., α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol showed antibacterial activity due to the presence of the hydroxyl group which can exchange protons and form hydrogen bonds with the electron-delocalized system enabling terpenoids to interact with microbial plasma membranes. This interaction induces conformational changes in the membrane structure, leading to ion imbalance, leakage, and ultimately cell death18,19. Moreover, the hydroxyl group found in terpenoids also contributes to a reduction in pH gradient across the cell membrane. This reduction leads to the collapse of the proton motive force and depletion of the ATP pool, ultimately culminating in cell death20.

Till date numerous researchers have reported the antibacterial potential of α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol19,21 but very few studies have been done on testing the antibacterial activity of their derivatives22 along with investigation of their synergistic interaction with standard antibiotic as well as antibiofilm potential. Thus, in continuation with our previous study10, in the present study, we have isolated α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol from two unique spices i.e., nutmeg (seed) and mace (skin of nutmeg seed) commonly named as ‘Jaiphal’ and ‘Javatri’ respectively, prepared their derivatizes and tested their antibacterial activity. The study was further extended to investigate theirs’ and the most effective derivative’s synergistic interaction with standard antibiotic, the antibiofilm activity of the most effective treatment; molecular docking studies to determine their binding affinity with DNA gyrase and transpeptidase, toxicity and drug-like properties analysis through absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion, and toxicity (ADMET) studies.

sec.title: Chemicals and reagents
sec.p: All the chemicals and reagents including hexane, ethyl acetate, dichloromethane, ethanol, pyridine, acetyl chloride, copper sulfate, silica gel, oxone, sodium bicarbonate, magnesium sulfate, acetone, n-propyl bromide, n-bromosuccinamide, carbon tetrachloride, dimethyl sulfoxide and crystal violet dye were of analytical grade and purchased from Sigma AdrichChemicals Pvt. Limited, Delhi. Standard antibiotic streptomycin was purchased from LobaChemie Pvt. Limited, Mumbai.

sec.title: Extraction and characterization of plant material
sec.p: Where tx= retention time of sample, tn and tn+1= Retention time of alkane standard having n, n + 1 carbons respectively.

Relative proportions of components in the essential oil were also measured using an Agilent 7890 A-GC-FID, under the same conditions as those used for GC-MS. Nitrogen was employed as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. The injector and detector temperatures were set at 250 and 300 °C respectively. The relative proportions of the components were calculated by dividing the area of each individual peak by the total area of all peaks, without considering the response factor.

sec.title: Isolation of α-terpineol from nutmeg essential oil
sec.p: The nutmeg essential oil showing the maximum antibacterial potential10 revealed the presence of α-terpineol (23.02%) in GC-MS analysis as a major compound which was further isolated via column chromatography. For this, the nutmeg essential oil (10 g) was chromatographed over silica gel (600 g). The column was eluted with hexane and polarity was increased gradually using dichloromethane (DCM). Fractions obtained by using hexane: dichloromethane (80:20) and (70:30) were pooled and further subjected to a second column using silver nitrate impregnated silica gel. Elution of the column was carried out with hexane: ethyl acetate as a solvent system of increasing polarity24. Each fraction was assessed by using TLC. The α-terpineol was obtained as a pure compound (2.06 g) in fractions (95:5 and 94:6). The characterization of pure compound (I) thus obtained was done by spectroscopic analysis.

sec.title: Isolation of 4-carvomenthenol from Mace Oleoresin
sec.p: GC-MS analysis of mace oleoresin revealed the presence of major compound 4-carvomenthenol (12.40%) as a major compound which was further isolated via column chromatography. The mace oleoresin (10 g) was chromatographed over silica gel (600 g) and eluted with hexane and polarity was increased gradually using dichloromethane. Fractions obtained by using hexane: dichloromethane (90:10) and (80:20) as a solvent system were pooled and further subjected to second column having 200 g of silver nitrate impregnated silica gel using hexane: ethyl acetate as a solvent system of increasing polarity24. Each fraction was assessed by using TLC. The 4-carvomenthenol was obtained as a pure compound (1.04 g) in fraction with solvent ratio of 97:3. The characterization of pure compound (II) thus obtained was done by spectroscopic analysis.

sec.title: Esterification of α-terpineol
sec.p: To prepare the ester from α-terpineol, 1.0 g (6.5 mmol) of α-terpineol was mixed with 2.0 ml of acetyl chloride, followed by the addition of 2 ml of pyridine. The resulting blend was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. Subsequently, ethyl acetate (20 ml) was introduced into the reaction mixture, which was then partitioned with 20% w/v aqueous solution of copper sulfate pentahydrate (CuSO4·5H2O) in three 30 ml portions. After separating the organic (ethyl acetate) and aqueous phases, the organic phase was treated with a saturated solution of sodium chloride and then with anhydrous magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) to remove any residual water (Fig. 1A). A brown-colored solid product was obtained after evaporating the solvent with a rotary evaporator25. The product was purified by recrystallization using ethanol, the purity of the resulting compound (III) was assessed using TLC, and its structure was determined through spectroscopic techniques. The yield of purified compound (III) was calculated on weight (w/w) basis.

caption.p: Synthetic routes for different derivatives; (A) compound (III), (B) compound (IV), (C) compound (V), (D) compound (VI), (E) compound (VII) and (F) compound (VIII).

sec.title: Epoxidation of α-terpineol
sec.p: In order to synthesize α-terpineol epoxide, 0.8 g (5 mmol) of α-terpineol was mixed in 15 ml of acetone having 2.0 g (23.8 mmol) of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3). The solution was allowed to cool at 0 °C. Subsequently, a solution of oxone (2KHSO5·KHSO4·K2SO4, 4 g; 6.5 mmol) in 15 ml of water was slowly added to the cooled mixture. Once the reaction was complete (after 8 h), the resulting mixture was shifted into the separatory funnel and extracted with diethyl ether (2 × 25 ml). The combined ether layers were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate (Fig. 1B). Evaporation of the solvent yielded colorless needle-shaped crystals of the resulting product26. The resulting compound (IV) was purified using preparative TLC (hexane: ethyl acetate; 90:10), and its structure was determined through spectroscopic techniques. The yield of purified compound (IV) was calculated on weight (w/w) basis.

sec.title: Williamson ether synthesis of α-terpineol
sec.p: 1.5 g (10 mmol) of α-terpineol, 20 ml of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and 5.0 g (125 mmol) of NaOH were heated at 90–110 °C with constant stirring. After the precipitates changed their appearance from slimy form to granular, 5.5 ml of n-propyl bromide was added slowly by maintaining the temperature at 100 °C. The reaction was continued for 8–9 h. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool down followed by sufficient addition of water to mix the precipitates. The extraction of the aqueous phase was done thrice with diethyl ether and any moisture left was removed by anhydrous sodium sulfate followed by ether removal by distillation (Fig. 1C)27. The resulting compound was purified using preparative TLC (hexane: ethyl acetate; 80:10). The structure of the final compound (V) obtained was determined by spectroscopic techniques and its yield was calculated on weight (w/w) basis.

sec.title: Allylic bromination of α-terpineol
sec.p: To carry out the allylic bromination, 0.16 g (1.0 mmol) of n-bromosuccinamide was added to 1.4 g (10 mmol) of α-terpineol with 10 mg (0.05 mmol) of benzoyl peroxide as a catalyst. The reaction mixture was added to 10 ml of carbon tetrachloride as a solvent and heated for 15 h at 85 °C with constant stirring. The red-colored reaction mixture obtained was cooled and the solid material formed was filtered away. To the filtrate, 50 ml diethyl ether was added and washed with sodium bicarbonate solution and sodium sulphite (50 ml; 1:1) in a separatory funnel. The organic layer was separated followed by drying with anhydrous MgSO4. The organic layer was then evaporated and a concentrated mixture of products was obtained. The brominated product formed was isolated and purified through preparative TLC using hexane: ethyl acetate (80:20) as the mobile phase (Fig. 1D)28. Finally, the structure of the compound (VI) obtained was determined by spectroscopic techniques and its yield was calculated on weight (w/w) basis.

sec.title: Esterification of 4-carvomenthenol
sec.p: To prepare the ester, 1.0 g (6.5 mmol) of 4-carvomenthenol was mixed with 2.0 ml of acetyl chloride, followed by the addition of 2 ml of pyridine. The resulting blend was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. Subsequently, ethyl acetate (20 ml) was introduced into the reaction mixture, which was then partitioned with a 20% w/v aqueous solution of copper sulfate pentahydrate (CuSO4·5H2O) in three 30 ml portions. After separating the organic (ethyl acetate) and aqueous phases, the organic layer was treated with NaCl solution (saturated) and then with anhydrous MgSO4 to remove any residual water (Fig. 1E). A brown-colored solid product was obtained after evaporating the solvent by rotary evaporator25. The product was purified by recrystallization using ethanol, the purity of the resulting compound (VII) was assessed using TLC, and its structure was determined through spectroscopic techniques. The yield of purified compound (VII) was calculated on weight (w/w) basis.

sec.title: Epoxidation of 4-carvomenthenol
sec.p: To synthesize 4-carvomenthenol epoxide, 0.8 g (5 mmol) of 4-carvomenthenol was mixed in 15 ml of acetone having 2.0 g (23.8 mmol) of NaHCO3. The solution was allowed to cool at 0 °C. Subsequently, a solution of oxone (2KHSO5·KHSO4·K2SO4, 4 g; 6.5 mmol) in 15 ml of water was slowly added to the cooled mixture. Once the reaction was complete (after 8 h), the resulting mixture was shifted into the separatory funnel and extracted with diethyl ether two times (2 × 25 ml). The combined ether layers were dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate (Fig. 1F). Evaporation of the solvent yielded colorless needle-shaped crystals of the resulting product26. The resulting compound (IV) was purified using preparative TLC (hexane: ethyl acetate; 9:1), and its structure was determined through spectroscopic techniques. The yield of purified compound (VIII) was calculated on weight (w/w) basis.
The physical properties and spectroscopic data of isolated compounds (I) and (II) and their derivative compounds (III-VIII) have been given below:

sec.title: Antibacterial activity of isolated pure compounds and their derivatives
sec.p: The antibacterial potential of α-terpineol, 4-carvomenthenol and their derivatives was screened against E. coli, Y. enterocolitica, S. aureus and Bacillus sp. by agar well diffusion method (concentration range 50–1000 µg/ml) as per the methodology given in our previous communication10.

sec.title: Cell constituent release study
sec.p: The release of constituents from the bacterial cells into the supernatant was studied as per the method given by Heena et al.29 with minor modifications. The cells were collected by centrifugation of 100 ml of bacterial cultures for 10 min at 5000 rpm followed by their washing with double distilled water (three times) and resuspension in 0.1 M phosphate buffer saline (pH 7.0). Then 100 ml of bacterial cell suspensions were treated with test compounds (I-VIII) at their MIC values and kept in incubator for 1 h at 37 °C. From these, 2 ml of the sample was taken and centrifuged for 2 min at 12,000 rpm. The cell constituent release was studied by observing the absorbance of 1 ml of supernatant (from each sample) at 260 nm under UV-Visible spectrophotometer (Perkin–Elmer 45). The absorption of the suspension, prepared with PBS (pH 7.0) and containing the same concentration of test compounds, was adjusted after 2 min of contact with the test bacterial strains. The control cells (untreated) were similarly corrected with PBS (pH 7.0).

sec.title: Synergistic potential
sec.p: FICA represented the MIC of each treatment in combination divided by the MIC of the treatment alone, while FICB represented the MIC of the synthetic antibiotic in combination divided by the MIC of the antibiotic alone. Interpretation of the FICI values indicated the nature of the interaction between the treatments: FICI ≤ 0.5 indicated synergistic interaction, 0.5 < FICI ≤ 1 indicated an additive effect, 1 < FICI ≤ 4 indicated indifference or no effect, and FICI > 4 indicated antagonistic effects31.

sec.title: Antibiofilm potential
sec.p: The test components showing the synergistic interaction with streptomycin against all the test bacteria was further studied for its antibiofilm activity, alone as well as in combination with streptomycin. The crystal violet method was used to assess the antibacterial mechanism by estimating the specific biofilm formation (SBF) by using UV- spectroscopy32.

where AB represents the OD at 570 nm of the attached and stained bacteria, CW represents the OD at 570 nm of the stained control tubes containing only bacteria-free medium, and G represents the OD at 630 nm of cell growth in broth33. Further, there were three categories of SBF values:
If strong biofilm is formed; SBF > 2.00.
For intermediate biofilm; SBF range between 1 and 2.
For weak biofilm formation; SBF < 1.00.

sec.title: Molecular docking studies
sec.p: Two enzymes DNA gyrase (PDB: 1KZN)34 and a transpeptidase, penicillin-binding protein 2a (PBP2a, PDB: 1MWT)35 were obtained from the Protein Data Bank for molecular docking studies. These enzymes were further prepared for docking by removing all water molecules and cognate ligands from PDB files and grid boxes of dimensions 100 Å × 98 Å × 90 Å (scaling factor: 0.475 Å) and 68 Å × 54 Å × 124 Å (scaling factor: 0.999 Å) were defined to accommodate the whole target enzymes, respectively using AutodockTools436. 3D structures of three compounds (α-terpineol ester, 4-carvomenthenol ester and Streptomycin) were downloaded from PubChem (https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) and prepared by defining the root and assigning the Gasteiger charges using AutodockTools436,37. For both enzymes, our docking protocol employed AutoDock-GPU4 (v1.5) and consists of the 1000 iterations of gradient-based local search methods (ADADELTA)38, where the initial first generation was predicted by the Solis-Wets (SW) local search algorithm39. Further, 500 Lamarckian genetic algorithm (LGA)40 runs for global search were included over a population of 300 individuals. The final analysis and visualization of the ligand binding site was done using PyMol41 and Discovery Studio42.

For validation of the adopted docking protocol, re-docking of the cognate ligands, clorobiocin and penicillin G was carried out into their respective target enzymes—DNA gyrase and PBP2a respectively. The RMSD values have also been determined to confirm the reliability of the model.

sec.title: Physiochemical and ADMET analysis
sec.p: The different pharmacokinetic properties of α-terpineol ester and 4-carvomenthenol ester were investigated through ADMET (Absorption, Distribution, Metabolism, Excretion, Toxicity) analysis, which offers crucial insights into the molecules’ drug-ability potential43. The present study involves the investigation of Lipinski parameters (physiochemical properties) ADMET profiles of ester derivatives. The 3D structures of both ester derivatives were converted to SMILES format using OpenBabel44. These SMILES strings were fed into ADMETlab 3.0 (https://admetlab3.scbdd.com/) to investigate their toxicity and pharmacokinetic properties.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The results were presented as mean values with their corresponding standard deviations. To investigate the antibacterial activity, ANOVA followed by Tukey’s B test was conducted using SAS, with statistical significance set at p < 0.0545.

sec.title: Isolation and derivatization of major compounds
sec.p: GC-MS analysis of nutmeg essential oil and mace oleoresin revealed α-terpineol (23.02%) and 4-carvomenthenol (12.40%) as major compounds respectively (Table S1, S2 and Fig. S1, S1) which were isolated in pure form by column chromatography as colorless viscous liquids in solvent system of hexane: ethylacetate (95:1) and 97:3 respectively with yield of 35 and 22% respectively. The isolated α-terpineol (I) was derivatized into α-terpineol ester (III), α-terpineol epoxide (IV), α-terpineol ether (V), 3-Bromo terpineol (VI), and 4-carvomenthenol (II) was derivatized into 4-carvomenthenol ester (VII) and 4-carvomenthenol epoxide (VIII). The structure elucidation of isolated compounds and their derivatives was carried out by FT-IR and1HNMR spectroscopic techniques (Figs. S3-S18) and by reference to the published data in the literature18,46–49.

sec.title: Antibacterial activity of isolated and derivatized compounds
sec.p: The isolated major compounds i.e., α-terpineol (I) and 4-carvomenthenol (II) and their derivatized compounds (III–VIII) were tested for their antibacterial activity where all the derivatives revealed greater antibacterial potential as compared to their parent compounds. The results were expressed in terms of inhibition zone diameter (Tables 1, 2, 3 and 4) and MIC values (Fig. 2). All the test components revealed significant antibacterial activity being more effective towards Gram-positive bacteria than Gram-negative bacteria. It has been found that compound (VII) being 4-carvomenthenol ester showed a maximum zone of inhibition @1000 µg/ml against Gram-positive bacteria i.e., 37.22 and 33.14 mm against Bacillus sp. and S. aureus respectively (Fig. 3), whereas, compound (III) being α-terpineol ester exhibited maximum zone of inhibition @1000 µg/ml against Gram-negative bacteria i.e., 27.65 and 22.51 mm against Y. enterocolitica and E. coli (Fig. 4). From the MIC values, it has been observed that compound (VII) showed the MIC values of 40, 65, 145 and 170 µg/ml against Bacillus sp., S. aureus, Y. enterocolitica and E. coli respectively. On the other hand, compound (III) showed the MIC values of 75, 105, 120 and 155 µg/ml respectively. Based upon the MIC values, the decreasing order of sensitivity of bacterial strains towards different test components followed the order: Bacillus sp. > S. aureus > Y. enterocolitica > E. coli.
The order of antibacterial activity of isolated major compounds and their derivatives against different test bacteria is as shown below:
Streptomycin > VII > III > V > VIII > IV > VI > II > I (Bacillus sp. and S. aureus).
Streptomycin > III > VII > IV > VIII > VI > V > I > II (Y. enterocolitica and E. coli).
All the results were significantly different from each other (mean values with different superscripts) as analysed by two-way ANOVA followed by Tukey B test at significance level of p < 0.05.

caption.p: MIC values of isolated major compounds and their derivatives against all the test bacteria. Values with different superscripts represent the significant difference at p < 0.05 using Tukey-B test.

sec.p: The enhanced antibacterial activity of esters may be due to their increased lipophilic character as compared to the parent alcohols which enhanced their ability to penetrate the microbial cell membranes. This increased penetration allows them to disrupt cellular processes more effectively, leading to higher antimicrobial efficacy50. This fact also got support from the work done by Kopecna et al.51 where esters of various terpene alcohols have been reported as skin penetration enhancers. The greater antibacterial potential of geranyl cinnamate against E. coli and S. aureus has been reported due to synergistic interaction of its substrates i.e., geraniol and cinnamic acid52. Mathela et al.53 observed that thymol ester derivatives exhibited enhanced activity against Gram-positive strains. Specifically, 2-isopropyl-5-methylphenyl acetate and 2-isopropyl-5-methylphenyl isobutyrate showed greater effectiveness than thymol itself against S. mutans (MIC = 11.7 and 93.7 µM), B. subtilis (MIC = 11.7 and 46.8 µM), and S. epidermidis (MIC = 11.7 and 46.8 µM). Our results were further supported by da Silva et al.54 who synthesized the eugenol ester derivative and reported the greater antibacterial activity of eugenol ester (MIC = 500 µg/mL) in comparison to the parent compound eugenol (MIC = 1000 µg/mL) against E. coli. Moreover, various ester derivatives of polyether antibiotics- salinomycin and blasticidin (peptidyl nucleoside) have been reported to have enhanced antibacterial activity as compared to their parent compounds55,56. Lather et al.57 also reported the potent antimicrobial potential of p-nitro aniline derivative of naringenin against S. aureus and E. coli having pMIC = 1.49 µM/mL.

sec.title: Cell constituents release study
sec.p: The release of bacterial cell constituents indicated irreversible damage to cell membranes caused by the treatment with test components. In comparison to the control, all the test samples revealed a significant enhancement in the release of cellular contents in all the tested bacteria as represented by the rise in OD values (Fig. 5). The derivatives resulted in greater cellular content release as compared to the parent compounds. Compound VII caused the highest release of cellular contents in Gram-positive strains i.e., Bacillus sp. with a maximum OD value (0.885 ± 0.11) and S. aureus (OD; 0.789 ± 0.15), whereas, compound III caused the highest release of cellular contents in Gram-negative strains i.e., Y. enterocolitica (OD; 0.715 ± 0.01) and E. coli (OD; 0.645 ± 0.11). However, among the parent compounds (I and II), compound I caused greater cell constituent release in Gram-negative bacteria and compound II caused greater cell constituent release in Gram-positive bacteria.

caption.p: Effect of isolated major compounds and their derivatives on release of cell components in tested bacterial strains. Values with different superscripts represent the significant difference at p < 0.05 using Tukey-B test.

sec.p: Our results also got support from the study of Song et al.58 where ferulic acid esters revealed greater cell content release (protein and nucleic acid) from Pseudomonas aeruginosa as shown by membrane hyperpolarization than ferulic acid. In another study, Shi et al.59 reported that alkyl ferulate esters significantly compromised E. coli cytomembranes resulting in the leakage of cellular constituents from E. coli such as nucleotides, proteins, potassium ions, and β-galactosidase.

Regarding the bacterial cell constituents release studies of major compounds (α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol), it has been reported that α-terpineol compromised the integrity and permeability of bacterial cell membranes resulting in cell lysis through the dissolution of the cell wall60. Li et al.61 studied the mode of action of α-terpineol on E. coli and suggested direct alterations in the bacterial cell membrane structure causing unequal division, plasmolysis and loss of cytoplasm.

sec.title: Synergistic interaction of compounds (I), (II), (III) and (VII) with standard antibiotic
sec.p: The synergistic effect resulting from the interaction of synthetic antibiotics and plant based natural compounds acts as a complementary strategy to restrict the dosage of synthetic antibiotics thereby reducing their adverse effects29. The reason behind the synergistic action can be explained by the fact that when plant extracts are combined with synthetic antibiotics, they tend to lower their MIC values due to the presence of a mixture of bioactive components in these extracts that enhance the antimicrobial efficacy of antibiotics30. The synergistic interaction of isolated major compounds (I) and (II) and the most effective derivatives i.e., their ester (III) and (VII) was studied with streptomycin. The results revealed that the compound (VII) (at 1/8 of MIC against Bacillus sp. and S. aureus, and 1/4 of MIC against Y. enterocolitica and E. coli) showed a synergistic interaction with streptomycin (at 1/32 of MIC against Bacillus sp., 1/16 of MIC against S. aureus, Y. enterocolitica, and E. coli) having FICI < 0.5 against all the tested bacteria (Table 5). Compound (III) (at 1/8, 1/4 and 1/4 of MIC) showed a synergistic effect with streptomycin (at 1/16, 1/16 and 1/8 of MIC) against Bacillus sp., S. aureus and Y. enterocolitica with FICI of 0.188, 0.312 and 0.375 respectively, whereas it exhibited additive effect with streptomycin against E. coli with FICI = 0.625. The pure compound (II) (at 1/2 of MIC) in combination with streptomycin (at 1/16, 1/8 and 1/4 of MIC) revealed the additive effect against Bacillus sp., S. aureus and Y. enterocolitica with FICI of 0.562, 0.625 and 0.750 respectively, whereas their combination showed indifferent behaviour against E. coli with FICI value 1.50. On the other hand, pure compound (I) in combination with streptomycin showed an additive effect against Bacillus sp. and S. aureus having FICI of 0.750 and 1.00 respectively. The pure compounds exhibited indifferent interaction against Y. enterocolitica and E. coli with FICI of 1.50 and 2.00 respectively.

caption.p: Synergistic interaction of isolated major compounds and their ester derivatives in combination with streptomycin.

table-wrap-foot.p: MICa= MIC of test component alone, MICc= MIC of sample in combination with antibiotic streptomycin (SMN). Results are expressed as synergy (S, FICI ≤ 0.5), Additive (A, 0.5 < FICI ≤ 1), Indifferent (I, 1 ≤ FICI ≤ 4) or antagonism (AN, FICI > 4).

sec.p: In support of our study, numerous researchers have reported the synergistic potential of α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol with either standard antibiotics or any other natural bioactive metabolite. Johansen et al.19 revealed the synergistic interaction between 4-carvomenthenol (concentration 0.039-2.5%) and α-terpineol (concentration 0.001-2.5%) against S. aureus, MRSA, E. coli and P. aeruginosa with FICI ≤ 0.5 against all the tested bacterial strains. Cordeiro et al.62 revealed the synergistic effect of 4-carvomenthenol with cefazolin, oxacillin and meropenem with FICI values to be 0.50, 0.32 and 0.50 respectively against S. aureus but synergy was not noted with vancomycin and gentamicin.

sec.title: Antibiofilm activity of the most effective ester derivatives (III and VII) alone and in combination with standard antibiotic
sec.p: Biofilm is the collective structure formed by bacterial colonies within a self-produced matrix. This matrix offers protection to the bacteria against challenging environmental conditions. It is one of the key factors in extending bacterial infection by shielding the bacteria from the action of antibiotics63. As the ester derivatives i.e., compound (VII) and (III) exhibited maximum antibacterial potential among all the test components and synergistic/additive interaction with standard antibiotic (streptomycin), thus they were further examined for their antibiofilm potential alone and in combination with streptomycin. The results were represented in terms of Specific biofilm formation (SBF) values.

In has been observed that the compound (VII) and (III) in combination with streptomycin showed a significant decrease in biofilm formation in all the tested bacteria as indicated by no ring formation/distorted ring in the crystal violet assay (Figs. 6 and 7). The compound (VII) when tested alone @ MIC revealed intermediate biofilm formation against E. coli and Bacillus sp. (SBF values 1.81 and 1.11 respectively) and strong biofilm formation against Y. enterocolitica and S. aureus (SBF values 2.22 and 2.35 respectively). Whereas, compound (III) @ MIC revealed intermediate biofilm formation against E. coli and S. aureus (SBF values 1.88 and 1.58 respectively) and strong biofilm formation against Bacillus sp. and Y. enterocolitica (SBF value 2.13 and 2.54 respectively). However, the combination of compound (VII) @ MIC/8 with streptomycin @ MIC/32 revealed weak biofilm formation with SBF value of 0.68 against Bacillus sp. Also, weak biofilm formation was observed by the combination of compound (VII) @ MIC/4 with streptomycin @ MIC/16 with SBF value 0.98 against E. coli. Whereas, intermediate biofilm formation was observed by the combination of compound (VII) with streptomycin with SBF values of 1.05 and 1.37 against S. aureus and Y. enterocolitica. On the other hand, compound (III) @ MIC/8 in combination with streptomycin @ MIC/16 showed intermediate biofilm formation against Bacillus sp. (SBF = 1.25) and weak biofilm was formed against all other test bacteria at different combinations (Table 6). Hence, it can be concluded that the combination of compound (VII) and (III) with streptomycin led to a significant decrease in the biofilm formation (p < 0.05).

caption.p: Ring formation using crystal violet assay in control (A), compound (VII) alone @MIC (B), compound (VII) in combination with standard (C) and standard alone (D) against Bacillus sp. (i), S. aureus (ii), Y. enterocolitica (iii), E. coli (iv).

Ring formation using crystal violet assay in control (A), compound (IV) alone @MIC (B), in compound (III) in combination with standard (C) and standard alone (D) against Bacillus sp.(i), S. aureus (ii), E. coli (iii), Y. enterocolitica (iv).
Antibiofilm potential of compound (VII) and (III) alone and in combination with streptomycin.

sec.p: In favour of our results, Song et al.58 reported the antibiofilm potential of alkyl ferulic acid esters against P. aeruginosa with hexyl ferulate revealing the maximum potential inhibiting 78% followed by propyl ferulate inhibiting 43% of biofilm formation. It resulted in wrinkled and rough cell surface followed by aggregation, adhesion and rupturing of cell. Cordeiro et al.62 revealed the strong antibiofilm potential of 4-carvomenthenol against S. aureus inhibiting more than 80% of biofilm formation at 0.5MIC and 90% inhibition was observed at a concentration of 2MIC and 4MIC. Moreover, numerous studies have shown that terpinen-4-ol exhibited promising efficacy in combating biofilms produced by oral pathogens such as Porphyromonas gingivalis, Fusobacterium nucleatum, Streptococcus mutans, and Lactobacillus acidophilus64–66.

sec.title: Molecular docking studies
sec.p: Molecular docking studies are used to identify effective drug candidates by observing how a drug-like molecule will interact with the target protein thus aiding in understanding the molecular mechanism67. DNA gyrase (type II topoisomerase), the key bacterial enzyme is involved in bacterial DNA replication, transcription and in catalyzing its negative supercoiling. Thus, it serves as an important target for antibacterial drugs. Another key target enzyme is transpeptidase, penicillin-binding protein 2a which facilitates the nucleophilic carbonyl substitution reaction and is essential for cross-linking peptidoglycan in the cell wall of bacteria29. Hence in the present study, molecular docking of both the ester derivatives being the most effective was carried out to predict their interaction with the binding sites of DNA gyrase (PDB: 1KZN) and transpeptidase, penicillin-binding protein 2a (PBP2a, PDB: 1MWT).

Both the ester derivatives displayed favorable binding affinities with the targeted proteins ranged from − 6.56 to − 4.31 kcal/mol (Table 7). However, they exhibited more binding affinity with DNA gyrase than transpeptidase, penicillin-binding protein 2a. The docking scores and various interactions involving hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic and Van der Waals interactions are represented in Table 7. It has been found that after streptomycin (–6.56 kcal/mol), α-terpineol ester showed a greater binding affinity (-6.11 kcal/mol) than 4-carvomenthenol ester (-5.42 kcal/mol) with DNA gyrase (Fig. 8). α-Terpineol ester formed one hydrogen bond with Val167, one hydrophobic interaction with Ile78 and twelve Van der Waals interactions with Ala47, Asp73, Asn46, Thr165, Val43, Val71, Met166, Met91, Val120, Gln72, Gly77, Glu50 amino acid residues. 4-Carvomenthenol ester showed hydrophobic interactions with four amino acid residues (Ile78, Ala47, Val43, Val167) with zero hydrogen bonding and three Van der Waals interactions with Asn46, Val71, Glu50 residues.

caption.p: Representation of the binding of three compounds (Streptomycin, α-terpineol ester and 4-carvomenthenol ester) to DNA gyrase (PDB: 1KZN). Grey cartoon on the top left represents the overlays of the docked compounds and the cognate ligand bound to DNA Gyrase, where the docked compounds are color coded. Each rectangular box depicts the binding pockets constituted by amino acids, represented by circles that indicate their chain ID and residue number. The docked compounds are shown in sticks and docking scores (kcal mol–1) are provided for each complex.
The binding affinity of DNA gyrase and transpeptidase with ester derivatives and streptomycin.

sec.p: In the case of transpeptidase, penicillin-binding protein 2a (PBP2a, PDB: 1MWT), α-terpineol ester showed the maximum binding affinity (-4.82 kcal/mol) followed by streptomycin (-4.39 kcal/mol) and 4-carvomenthenol ester (-4.31 kcal/mol) (Fig. 9). α-Terpineol ester formed one hydrogen bond with Lys215, five hydrophobic interactions with Val217, Pro370, Lys218, Lys219, Tyr369 residues and six Van der Waals interactions with Leu224, Leu190, Glu379, Thr216, Tyr373, Asp367. 4-Carvomenthenol ester formed two hydrogen bonds with Lys218, Lys219 residues, three hydrophobic interactions with Val217, Pro370, Tyr373 residues and six Van der Waals interactions with Lys215, Asp367, Thr216, Tyr369, Asp221, Leu224 residues. For validation of the adopted docking protocol, the cognate ligands, clorobiocin and penicillin G, were re-docked into their respective target enzymes - DNA gyrase and PBP2a respectively (Fig. 10). In both cases, the predicted binding pocket was observed to be similar to the original pocket (Fig. 10). Moreover, the superposition of Autodock-generated ligand conformations onto their receptive original crystal structure conformations resulted in reasonable agreement. All these observations as well as RMSD values confirmed the suitability of our docking protocol to computationally analyse DNA gyrase and PBP2a enzymes. Our results were in consonance to Dubar et al.68 who reported the ciprofloxacin ester derivatives as potent DNA gyrase inhibitors in docking studies. Hossen et al.69 also revealed very good binding affinity of geranyl acetate with DNA gyrase and transpeptidase.

caption.p: Representation of the binding of three compounds (Streptomycin, α-terpineol ester and 4-carvomenthenol) to the penicillin-binding protein 2a (PBP2a, PDB: 1MWT). Red cartoon on the top represents the overlays of the docked compounds and the cognate ligand bound to PBP2a, where docked compounds are color coded. Each rectangular box depicts the binding pockets constituted by amino acids, represented by circles that indicate their chain ID and residue number. The docked compounds are shown in sticks and docking scores (kcal mol–1) are provided for each complex.

(A) The original and docked poses of the cognate ligand (clorobiocin) bound to DNA gyrase (grey cartoon) are represented by black and yellow sticks respectively, with their superpositions shown at the bottom. (B) The original and docked poses of the cognate ligand (penicillin G) bound to PBP2a (red cartoon), are represented by black and cyan sticks respectively, with their superposition shown at the bottom. RMSD values are also provided.

sec.title: Physiochemical properties
sec.p: The term ‘physicochemical’ refers to the ‘drug-likeness’ of a molecule, which influences its ability to function as an oral drug in terms of bioavailability. This is a crucial phase in the drug development, following discovery and involves comprehensive studies on the drug’s formulation, pharmacokinetics, stability, toxicity, and metabolism29. The difference between drug-like and non-drug-like characteristics of molecules in the early stages of drug development is determined by specific physicochemical properties assessed using Lipinski’s Rule of Five. It includes different ranges for various physicochemical properties that determine the molecule’s potential for oral bioavailability43.

Both the ester derivatives exhibited all the physiochemical properties within the required range (Table 8). As both the ester derivatives are structural isomers of each other, most of the physiochemical properties have the same values. The drug molecule’s ability to pass through the cell membrane has been influenced by factors like molecular weight and topological polar surface area (TPSA). In this study, the molecular weight of both compounds fell within the acceptable range (100–600 Da), and the TPSA of both compounds was within the desired range (0–140), suggesting their potential for in vivo permeability. Furthermore, the ability of a drug molecule to traverse the cell’s bilayer membrane is influenced by the number of hydrogen bond acceptors (nHA, ideally ≤ 10) and donors (nHD, ideally ≤ 5). Here, both the compounds showed acceptable limits of nHA and nHD (Table 8). Another important parameter is LogP, whose value lower than 5 is considered favourable for optimal absorption rates. It defines lipophilicity in terms of the logarithm of the distribution coefficient between organic and aqueous phases70. Here, both the ester derivatives showed a desirable value of LogP i.e. <5 (Table 8).

caption.p: Physiochemical properties of α-terpineol ester and 4-carvomenthenol ester.

table-wrap-foot.p: Number of heteroatoms (nHet), formal charge (fChar), number of rigid bonds (nRig), number of hydrogen bond acceptors (nHA), number of hydrogen bond donors (nHD), number of rotatable bonds (nRot), topological polar surface area (TPSA), drug solubility (LogS), Distribution coefficient (LogD), lipophilicity (LogP).

sec.p: Other than Lipinski parameters, nRot i.e., the number of rotatable bonds indicated the potential of drug molecules for oral bioavailability and its value should range between 0 and 11. In this study, both the ester derivatives have 3 rotatable bonds thus representing their strong oral bioavailability potential. However, the presence of an excessive number of rigid bonds (nRig) (optimal 0–30) can increase molecular complexity, which may negatively impact the oral bioavailability of a substance. Here, both the derivatives have an acceptable number of rigid bonds (Table 8).

Both the ester derivatives possessed zero formal charge (fChar, optimal − 4 to 4) which means that the enzymes responsible for drug metabolism can effectively interact with charged sites, potentially altering the normal distribution of drug molecules within the body. Also, a higher number of heteroatoms (nHet) suggested enhanced reactivity and a greater potential for particular type of interaction, with the optimal range between 1 and 15. Both the compounds in this study displayed nHet values within this limit (Table 8). Additionally, the LogS value indicates drug solubility, with lower values being preferred. Both the ester derivatives exhibited LogS value within the range of − 4 to 0.5 log mol/L. Distribution coefficient (LogD, optimal 1–3) influence the drug permeability by affecting the lipophilicity of ionizable compounds. Here, both the compounds also exhibited permissible value for LogD (Table 8).

sec.title: ADMET analysis
sec.p: The pharmacokinetic properties of both the ester derivatives were further studied by in silico ADMET analysis71. The optimal range of natural product (NP) score is -5 to 5, 4-carvomenthenol ester possessed greater natural product-likeness with NP score of 2.772 as compared to α-terpineol ester with NP score 2.192 (Table 9). Absorption parameters include Caco-2 permeability which indicates the absorption of drugs administered orally. The ideal value should be greater than − 5.15. Here, 4-carvomenthenol ester has greater Caco-2 permeability than α-terpineol ester (Table 9). P-glycoprotein (Pgp) is an efflux transporter that pumps drugs out of cells, potentially limiting their absorption and distribution. A low Pgp substrate value of 4-carvomenthenol ester (0.018) means the drug is less likely to be effluxed and has better potential for absorption and distribution throughout the body. Moreover, 4-carvomenthenol ester (0.009) showed slightly greater human intestinal absorption (HIA) than α-terpineol ester (0.006). Greater HIA indicates that the drugs exhibit more effective intestinal absorption after being taken orally. The various sugar esters revealed a greater HIA value in comparison to the parent galactose72.

caption.p: ADMET analysis of ester derivatives.

sec.p: In order to understand the distribution of drug molecules, blood brain barrier penetration (must be low for non-CNS drugs) and fraction unbound in plasma (must be low for favourable pharmacokinetics) were the key factors. These parameters revealed the greater acceptance of 4-carvomenthenol ester with lower values of both parameters in comparison to α-terpineol ester (Table 9). To study drug metabolism in humans, cytochrome P450 enzymes (CYP enzymes) are essential. CYPs are a superfamily of heme-containing proteins that facilitate the oxidative reactions of various compounds, including fatty acids, steroids, and xenobiotics. They play a crucial role in drug metabolism, accounting for around 50% of all metabolic processes involving drugs. CYPs catalyse several reactions, including C and O oxidation, O-dealkylation, N-dealkylation, S-oxidation, N-oxidation, aromatic hydroxylation, deamination, and dehalogenation. In humans, there are roughly 100 isoforms of CYPs, primarily acting in the liver73. Additionally, drug toxicities—including sub-therapeutic or supra-therapeutic effects, drug interactions, antagonism, accumulation, liver complications, and hepatotoxicity—are closely linked to the interaction of drugs with key cytochrome P-450 (CYP) mixed-function oxidase isoenzymes, specifically CYP1A2, CYP2C19, CYP2C9, CYP2D6, and CYP3A474. Ideally, antibiotics should be substrates for these enzymes, allowing them to be efficiently metabolized. This ensures the drug is processed and eliminated predictably, supporting stable pharmacokinetics. Lipophilicity plays a crucial role in the binding of a substrate to cytochrome P450. As lipophilicity increases, the metabolic clearance of a drug also tends to rise73. Antibiotics that do not significantly inhibit CYP enzymes are preferred, as they are less likely to disrupt the metabolism of other medications, thereby reducing the potential for harmful drug interactions75. Among both the esters, 4-carvomenthenol ester exhibited the greater substrate probability, thus predicting good rate of metabolism in comparison to α-terpineol ester (Table 9).

In excretion, the clearance (CL) parameter was studied whose normal limit ranges from 5 to 15 indicating moderate elimination of drug molecules from the body. The CL values of both ester derivatives lie within the required range and are comparable. Among toxicity parameters, both the ester derivatives showed little probability of oral acute toxicity, carcinogenicity and respiratory toxicity. However, they may cause skin sensitization, eye irritation and eye corrosion to some extent with 4-carvomenthenol ester being less toxic than α-terpineol ester (Table 9).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Hence, out of α-terpineol, 4-carvomenthenol and their derivatives, α-terpineol ester and 4-carvomenthenol ester exhibited the strongest antibacterial activity by causing damage to the bacterial cell membrane leading to leakage of cellular components. Both the ester derivatives revealed synergistic interaction with streptomycin and showed intermediate to weak biofilm formation in combination with streptomycin. Among the ester derivatives, α-terpineol ester showed better binding with DNA gyrase and transpeptidase than 4-carvomenthenol ester. Both the ester derivatives also possessed favourable physicochemical properties and a strong pharmacokinetic profile, meeting all the criteria for drug likeliness. Therefore, both the ester derivatives can be considered promising antibacterial drug candidates. However, its effectiveness in animal infection models should be evaluated in future in vivo research.

sec.title: Future perspective
sec.p: The promising findings from this study on α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol esters highlight their potential as novel antimicrobial agents. Future research should focus on several key areas to fully explore and harness the therapeutic applications of these compounds. Conducting thorough safety and toxicity studies is essential to evaluate the viability of these compounds for therapeutic use. This includes in vivo studies to ensure safe application in clinical settings. The study of synergistic interactions between α-terpineol/4-carvomenthenol, α-terpineol ester /4-carvomenthenol ester and ester derivatives with other antibiotics may be carried forward so as to lower their MIC values. Along with this, future research may be directed towards the development of various nanoformulations of ester derivatives for their targeted and controlled release. Investigating the environmental effects of using these compounds, particularly in agricultural applications, will provide insights into their sustainability and potential for use in eco-friendly antimicrobial solutions. By addressing these areas, future research can significantly contribute to the development of α-terpineol and 4-carvomenthenol esters as viable antimicrobial agents, potentially leading to innovative treatments in the fight against infectious diseases.
